summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre Museum in Paris recently suffered a brazen daylight heist in which thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery and stole high-value jewelry, including damaging the crown of Empress Eugénie. The incident, which took only seven minutes and prompted a full museum closure, is part of a longer history of security failures. A 2019–2024 report by the Court of Auditors revealed persistent delays in updating security systems, with outdated equipment and poor implementation of renovations. This has been compounded by decades of issues such as overcrowding, water leaks, and temperature fluctuations that threaten artwork conservation. The Louvre has previously faced major thefts, including the 1911 'Mona Lisa' theft and the 1983 loss of 16th-century armor. In response, the museum president Laurence des Cars warned of deteriorating conditions, leading to plans for a major renovation and a dedicated room for the 'Mona Lisa' under President Emmanuel Macron's support. The events underscore the urgent need for improved infrastructure and security measures to protect one of the world’s most iconic cultural institutions.
title: Jewelry heist at the Louvre is latest problem to beset France’s most famous museum
